body:
The message in the log is the (failed) result of an attempt to authenticate a client (the protocol adapters I assume) by delegating to the auth server. This is probably due to the fact that the auth server is not (yet) up and running. However, because the protocol adapters try again and again to connect to the Hono server, the authentication request eventually succeeds and everything is fine. The failed connection attempts do not show up in the adapters' log by default.

I assume that the protocol adapters do work, don't they?

I have taken another look and I believe that the client (the protocol adapter in this case) currently is not able to handle this situation because the `HonoClient` does not re-try on an authentication failure (which makes kind of sense because the credentials will not suddenly be correct on the next attempt). I think we will need to prevent this from happening by means of making the Hono server open its ports only once the services it depends on become available, i.e. the Dispatch Router and the authentication server.

Yes, the authentication failure in the protocol adapter was indeed due to the auth server not being fully started yet.

Concerning the re-try: With the new setup of having an external Auth server, as it is currently implemented, an authentication failure doesn't necessarily mean that credentials are wrong - it can just be that the auth server is currently down.
Would it be possible to return a different error in that case (something like "service anavailable"), so that such an error can be handled with a re-try in the protocol adapter? 
If not, I would opt for an unconditional re-try or, as the adapter is in kind of dead state then, to shutdown the adapter.

> If not, I would opt for an unconditional re-try or, as the adapter is in kind of dead state then, to shutdown the adapter.

This is what I prefer as well. In conjunction with a *health check* HTTP resource provided by protocol adapters it should be possible for e.g. kubernetes to only expose working protocol adapter instances to external clients. So this is the approach I am following now ...

After having applied the workaround of restarting the adapters once the auth-server was fully started, the example scenario worked. Device registration was successful and telemetry data was sent and consumed successfully.

However, after a certain time, the adapters returned errors: `Error{condition=amqp:unauthorized-access, description='unauthorized', info=null}`

Here is the relevant log output of the **MQTT adapter**:
````

09:08:02.238 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] DEBUG o.e.h.c.i.AbstractRequestResponseClient - received response [correlation ID: reg-client-171, status: 200]

09:08:08.454 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] INFO o.e.h.a.m.VertxBasedMqttProtocolAdapter - Connection request from client esp8266.5ccf7f9509f1
09:08:08.518 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] DEBUG o.e.hono.client.impl.HonoClientImpl - reusing existing registration client for [DEFAULT_TENANT]
09:08:08.519 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] DEBUG o.e.hono.client.impl.HonoClientImpl - reusing existing message sender [target: telemetry/DEFAULT_TENANT, credit: 211]
````

````
09:08:22.408 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-1] DEBUG org.eclipse.hono.server.HonoServer - subject [mqtt-adapter@HONO] is not authorized to WRITE to [telemetry/DEFAULT_TENANT]
09:08:23.102 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-1] DEBUG org.eclipse.hono.server.HonoServer - client [Hono REST Adapter-070fd1e4-18df-412b-946b-08d52e6816bb] wants to open a link for sending messages [address: Target{address='telemetry/DEFAULT_TENANT', durable=NONE, expiryPolicy=SESSION_END, timeout=0, dynamic=false, dynamicNodeProperties=null, capabilities=null}]
09:08:23.102 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-1] DEBUG org.eclipse.hono.server.HonoServer - subject [rest-adapter@HONO] is not authorized to WRITE to [telemetry/DEFAULT_TENANT]
09:08:28.660 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-1] DEBUG org.eclipse.hono.server.HonoServer - client [Hono MQTT Adapter-c6e41c84-1b38-46ef-b943-572630e28dd9] wants to open a link for sending messages [address: Target{address='telemetry/DEFAULT_TENANT', durable=NONE, expiryPolicy=SESSION_END, timeout=0, dynamic=false, dynamicNodeProperties=null, capabilities=null}]
09:08:28.660 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-1] DEBUG org.eclipse.hono.server.HonoServer - subject [mqtt-adapter@HONO] is not authorized to WRITE to [telemetry/DEFAULT_TENANT]
````

In the **auth-server** log, there is no output at all in that time period and later on. 

I've restarted the auth-server after that. But that didn't solve the problem. In the auth-server logs I saw no incoming requests at all.

Yes, I guess this is due to the JWT tokens expiring after around 10 minutes (does that match the time after which the errors show up in your case?).

We currently have no way of refreshing the tokens automatically. This requires some changes in the vertx-proton API (which I will do over the next days/weeks). For the time being, we will simply close the connection with the client (adapter) so that it re-establishes a connection and gets a fresh token.
Yes, it likely was such a 10min time frame after which errors occurred.

issue.title: Fix device registry certs not being based on the checked-in CA

body:
should be fixed in a70be270a72f71bc5ad60b785d0a1cc09f70c19d

@calohmn can you take it for a ride and see if this fixes the issue for you?

issue.title: No re-connection attempt from Hono to QPid after "Disconnected" exception
issue.body:
We got into a scenario, where the connection from Hono to the Dispatch Router got lost and a re-connection attempt was made. This connection attempt didn't succeed - a "Disconnected" exception was thrown. 
From then on, no re-connection attempts were made, leaving Hono in an unusable state.

Hono log output:
```
15:51:07.162 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-1] INFO o.e.h.c.ConnectionFactoryImpl - connecting to AMQP 1.0 container [amqps://qdrouter:5673]
15:51:07.548 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-1] INFO o.e.h.c.ConnectionFactoryImpl - connected to AMQP 1.0 container [amqps://qdrouter:5673], opening connection ...
15:51:07.552 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-1] INFO o.e.h.c.ConnectionFactoryImpl - connection to container [Hono.Example.Router] at [amqps://qdrouter:5673] open
15:51:11.564 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-1] WARN o.e.h.e.i.ForwardingEventDownstreamAdapter - lost connection to downstream container [Hono.Example.Router], closing upstream receivers ...
15:51:11.771 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-1] INFO o.e.h.e.i.ForwardingEventDownstreamAdapter - attempting to re-connect to downstream container
15:51:11.772 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-1] INFO o.e.h.config.ClientConfigProperties - using certificates from file [/run/secrets/trusted-certs.pem] as trust anchor
15:51:11.772 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-1] INFO o.e.h.config.ClientConfigProperties - using key & certificate from PKCS12 key store [/run/secrets/honoKeyStore.p12] for identity
15:51:11.772 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-1] INFO o.e.h.c.ConnectionFactoryImpl - connecting to AMQP 1.0 container [amqps://qdrouter:5673]
15:51:12.149 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-1] WARN o.e.h.c.ConnectionFactoryImpl - can't connect to AMQP 1.0 container [amqps://qdrouter:5673]
io.vertx.core.VertxException: Disconnected
	at io.vertx.proton.impl.ProtonClientImpl.lambda$null$0(ProtonClientImpl.java:74) ~[vertx-proton-3.4.1.jar!/:na]
	at io.vertx.proton.impl.ProtonConnectionImpl.fireDisconnect(ProtonConnectionImpl.java:370) ~[vertx-proton-3.4.1.jar!/:na]
	at io.vertx.proton.impl.ProtonTransport.handleSocketEnd(ProtonTransport.java:88) ~[vertx-proton-3.4.1.jar!/:na]
	at io.vertx.core.net.impl.NetSocketImpl.handleClosed(NetSocketImpl.java:297) ~[vertx-core-3.4.1.jar!/:na]
	at io.vertx.core.impl.ContextImpl.lambda$wrapTask$2(ContextImpl.java:335) ~[vertx-core-3.4.1.jar!/:na]
	at io.vertx.core.impl.ContextImpl.executeFromIO(ContextImpl.java:193) ~[vertx-core-3.4.1.jar!/:na]
	at io.vertx.core.net.impl.VertxHandler.channelInactive(VertxHandler.java:97) ~[vertx-core-3.4.1.jar!/:na]
	at io.netty.channel.AbstractChannelHandlerContext.invokeChannelInactive(AbstractChannelHandlerContext.java:246) ~[netty-transport-4.1.8.Final.jar!/:4.1.8.Final]
```

The dispatch router log didn't contain relevant output.

issue.title: [#203] New microservice that implements the device registry - so far â€¦
issue.body:
â€¦the credentials API is implemented as first step.

As a proposal I made a new Maven module "services" under which the maven module "device-registry" is hosted. 
Alternatively the device-registry could be at the top level as well - to me it seems to be a cleaner structure with the "services" module. Feedback welcome of course - if agreed on, the auth-server might move there as well (?).

Steps to follow include:
- integration tests
- docker swarm setup
- registration API
- REST Adapter using the device registry instead of Hono for the registration API

Signed-off-by: Karsten Frank <Karsten.Frank@bosch-si.com>

issue.title: Memory leak in Hono components on AMQP connection re-connects
issue.body:
We have observed a memory leak caused by AMQP connection re-connects.

To reproduce:
- Start the Hono components
- Take a heap dump of the REST adapter
- Stop the device registry application
- notice the re-connect attempt log messages in the REST adapter
```
14:30:04.204 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] INFO  o.e.hono.client.impl.HonoClientImpl - attempting to re-connect to server [localhost:26671]
14:30:04.204 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] INFO  o.e.h.c.ConnectionFactoryImpl - connecting to AMQP 1.0 container [amqps://localhost:26671]
14:30:04.707 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] INFO  o.e.h.c.ConnectionFactoryImpl - can't connect to AMQP 1.0 container [amqps://localhost:26671]: Verbindungsaufbau abgelehnt: localhost/127.0.0.1:26671
14:30:04.707 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] DEBUG o.e.hono.client.impl.HonoClientImpl - scheduling re-connect attempt ...
14:30:05.208 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] INFO  o.e.hono.client.impl.HonoClientImpl - attempting to re-connect to server [localhost:26671]
14:30:05.208 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] INFO  o.e.h.c.ConnectionFactoryImpl - connecting to AMQP 1.0 container [amqps://localhost:26671]
14:30:05.713 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] INFO  o.e.h.c.ConnectionFactoryImpl - can't connect to AMQP 1.0 container [amqps://localhost:26671]: Verbindungsaufbau abgelehnt: localhost/127.0.0.1:26671
14:30:05.713 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] DEBUG o.e.hono.client.impl.HonoClientImpl - scheduling re-connect attempt ...
14:30:06.213 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] INFO  o.e.hono.client.impl.HonoClientImpl - attempting to re-connect to server [localhost:26671]
14:30:06.213 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] INFO  o.e.h.c.ConnectionFactoryImpl - connecting to AMQP 1.0 container [amqps://localhost:26671]
14:30:06.717 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] INFO  o.e.h.c.ConnectionFactoryImpl - can't connect to AMQP 1.0 container [amqps://localhost:26671]: Verbindungsaufbau abgelehnt: localhost/127.0.0.1:26671
14:30:06.717 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-0] DEBUG o.e.hono.client.impl.HonoClientImpl - scheduling re-connect attempt ...
```
- After some time take another heap dump of the REST adapter and compare it to the first one
=> this shows increased memory consumption

The heap dump diff shows additional `io.vertx.core.net.impl.NetClientImpl` objects (one for each connection attempt). They look like the main part of the memory leak.
